text: Professor Julian Taylor, C.B.E., M.S., F.R.C.S., Hon.F.R.A.C.S. (26 January 1889 - 15 April 1961) was a specialist in neurological surgery, Senior Surgeon at University College Hospital, a former Vice-President of the Royal College of Surgeons and later Professor of Surgery at the University of Khartoum. Born in St. John's Wood, London, his father was the artist Edward Ingram Taylor and his mother, Margaret Boole, came from a family of mathematicians (his aunt was Alicia Boole Stott and his grandfather was George Boole). His brother was the physicist Sir Geoffrey Ingram Taylor OM. Educated at University College School and University College Hospital, he qualified in 1911, an immediate disciple of Wilfred Trotter, one of the pioneers in neurosurgery, graduated M.B.,B.S., with honours in medicine in the following year and took the F.R.C.S. in 1914. ==References== *British Medical Journal obituary *Sudan Association of Surgeons ==External links== *Mycetoma Research Centre, Sudan *Memorial address by Mr. A. J. Gardham, F.R.C.S Category:English surgeons Category:Commanders of the Order of the British Empire Category:1889 births Category:1961 deaths Category:People educated at University College School Category:Fellows of the Royal College of Surgeons Category:University of Khartoum faculty Category:20th-century surgeons
title: Julian Taylor (surgeon)
